cycle_2_key_findings.finding_2: The Christensen sustaining/disruptive distinction is THE competitive lens for 2026. Across accounting, legal, and healthcare, well-funded competitors are building tools for incumbents. The disruptive opportunity (AI-first service for underserved markets) remains nearly empty.

cycle_summaries.summary: DEEPENING & CORRECTION cycle. Real data replaces estimates across manufacturing acquisition, food production, SBA 504, competitive density, and O*NET task classification. Scanned 38 signals including 10 counter-signals (2+ per Tier 1 opportunity). Constructed 34 business models. KEY CORRECTIONS: Legal AI DEMOTED from Tier 1 to Tier 2 (score -7, Lawhive $60M Series B closes service layer gap). Insurance Claims AI score -3 (4% scaling rate, 70% customer mistrust). Healthcare Admin AI score -2, REFRAMED to provider-side (WISeR vendor selection closed). Food/Beverage Production PROMOTED from Tier 2 to Tier 1 (score +2, confirmed with real listings and unit economics). Manufacturing Acquisition score +1, CONFIRMED with BizBuySell data and modeled capital stack. SBA 504 CORRECTED: first-time buyers need 15% down (not 10%). USDA VAPG corrected to $250K max. 2 new patterns identified: Embedded AI Commoditizing Tool Layer (P-011) and Provider-Side Healthcare AI Arms Race (P-012).

tier_1.name: SMB Accounting/Finance (Full-Service Layer)
tier_1.cycle_3_change: Score -1. Service layer no longer empty (Basis, Docyt). Embedded AI in Xero/Intuit threatens tool layer. FULL-SERVICE layer remains empty. Unit economics: $0.05/month inference per client. Target: 23M unserved single-entity SMBs.

tier_1.name: Healthcare Admin AI (Provider-Side)
tier_1.cycle_3_change: Score -2, REFRAMED. WISeR vendor selection CLOSED (6 vendors identified: Cohere, Genzeon, Humata, Innovaccer, Virtix, Zyter). Congressional repeal bill. PROVIDER-SIDE opportunity strengthened. Horizontal platform across ALL practice types = gap (competitors hyper-specialized). Arms race dynamic: payer AI vs provider AI.

tier_1.name: Robotics x AI Manufacturing Acquisition
tier_1.cycle_3_change: Score +1, CONFIRMED WITH REAL DATA. BizBuySell: 379 CA manufacturing for sale, median $600K. CNC shops: $1.25-3M asking, $1-2M revenue, $300-400K EBITDA. Capital stack modeled: $3M acquisition + $500K modernization, $18K/mo debt service covered by $29K/mo EBITDA. SBA 504 at 5.85%. CORRECTION: 15% equity for first-time buyers.

Unit economics modeled: acquire at $1-1.5M, add cobots $200-300K, margin uplift from 29% to 35-45%. BEST FIT for robotics x AI. USDA VAPG corrected to $250K max.

cycle_3_key_corrections.correction_1: SBA 504 equity requirement: cycle 2 stated 10% down for all. ACTUAL: first-time buyers (businesses <2 years) need 15% down. On a $3M acquisition: $450K equity (not $300K). Still achievable but higher bar.
cycle_3_key_corrections.correction_2: USDA VAPG amount: cycle 2 stated $200K max. ACTUAL: $250K max. Requires 1:1 match.
cycle_3_key_corrections.correction_3: Legal AI service layer: cycle 2 described as 'sparse.' Lawhive $60M Series B (Feb 5, 2026) reveals service layer RAPIDLY FILLING. Triggered demotion from Tier 1 to Tier 2 (score -7).
cycle_3_key_corrections.correction_4: Healthcare admin WISeR opportunity: cycle 2 framed as entering WISeR. Research shows vendor selection CLOSED and congressional repeal bill. Reframed to PROVIDER-SIDE (helping practices fight AI-powered denials).
cycle_3_key_corrections.correction_5: Manufacturing acquisition integration timeline: cycle 2 implied 3-6 months. Real data suggests 12-18 months realistic. 70% M&A synergy failure rate.

cycle_3_key_findings.finding_1: REAL ACQUISITION DATA confirms thesis: 379 CA manufacturing businesses for sale (median $600K), 77 food production (median $377K). CNC shops at $1.25-3M asking with $300-400K EBITDA. Retirement sales cluster at 3.2-4x EBITDA. Capital stack modeled: $18K/mo debt service covered by $29K/mo pre-modernization EBITDA.
cycle_3_key_findings.finding_2: Christensen three-layer framework is THE competitive insight for 2026. NEW: embedded AI from platform vendors (Xero, Intuit, Westlaw, EHRs) is commoditizing the tool layer. Service layer emerging but still sparse (Basis, Docyt for accounting; Lawhive, Garfield for legal; HealthSpark, Verse for healthcare). Full-service layer EMPTY across all sectors.
cycle_3_key_findings.finding_3: O*NET Polanyi classification provides quantitative backing: Bookkeepers 85-90% routine-cognitive (highest services automation potential), Medical Records 97% (deepest Baumol Cure), Machinists 30% routine-cognitive + 50% tacit-manual (partial enhancement, not replacement). Physical production automation is DIFFERENT from services automation.
cycle_3_key_findings.finding_4: Counter-signals are substantive, not dismissable: Lawhive $60M killed legal Tier 1 thesis. Insurance 4% scaling rate (vs 78% adoption) = real implementation barrier. 70% M&A failure rate adds realism to manufacturing. WISeR vendor selection closed. These corrections make the remaining opportunities MORE credible.
cycle_3_key_findings.finding_5: Capital allocation consensus is the STRONGEST yet: BlackRock ('humanoid robotics most transformative frontier'), JPM (AI supercycle broadening), Goldman ($500B+ AI investment, reindustrialization). All three major asset managers are bullish on physical-economy AI. This validates manufacturing/robotics/food production plays as fundable.

cycle_4_key_findings.finding_1: BAUMOL CURE PRIORITY MATRIX: First quantitative framework for ranking opportunities by total automatable wage bill. O*NET automation risk x BLS wages x employment = $207B across 7 key occupations. This is not an estimate -- it's calculated from government occupational and labor data. Accounting ($139B combined bookkeepers + accountants) is the largest automatable pool. Healthcare admin (medical records 97%) has the deepest automation potential but smaller employment base.
cycle_4_key_findings.finding_2: STRESS TESTS SURVIVED WITH ADJUSTMENTS: All top 3 survived stress testing. (1) SMB Accounting: Intuit Accountant Suite is the biggest threat but serves accountants (B2B2C), not SMBs directly. Bench $113M collapse validates market while proving AI+human hybrid fails -- pure AI solves it. Score -2 but thesis intact. (2) Manufacturing: Cobot ROI is PROVEN (8-14 months, $65-85K/yr). The kill risk is operational complexity (70% M&A failure), not technology. Score -1 but acquire-and-enhance model validated. (3) Food: Commodity margins (5-10%) are NOT viable. MUST filter for specialty/branded (20-35%). Score -1 with critical filter added.
cycle_4_key_findings.finding_3: DEAD BUSINESS REVIVAL IS A CROSS-SECTOR PATTERN: Bench ($113M, accounting) and Woebot ($123M, mental health) both collapsed with validated markets. Combined $236M in proved demand. Failure modes are DIFFERENT but both SOLVABLE: Bench's cost structure fails at AI+human hybrid but works at pure AI ($0.05/month). Woebot's regulatory path fails via FDA but works via sub-clinical. This is P4 (Dead Business Revival) operating at scale -- the richest vein of validated opportunity.
cycle_4_key_findings.finding_4: UNDER-EXPLORED SECTOR VERDICTS: Mental Health AI PROMOTED to Tier 2 (score 74) -- massive Jevons expansion (5-10x at $10-30/mo), P4 dead revival (Woebot $123M), regulatory moat forming (Utah HB 452), 3 viable sub-FDA paths. cycle_summaries.summary: BUSINESS MODEL DECOMPOSITION cycle  YC-granularity. Decomposed all 11 sectors (5 Tier 1, 6 Tier 2) into 102 specific, buildable business models. Each model scored INDEPENDENTLY on 5 new axes: competitive_density (inverted), unit_economics_clarity, distribution_specificity, moat_durability, customer_findability. Web search executed for ACTUAL competitors on each specific model. Top models cluster around 3 themes: (1) Dead Business Revival plays targeting orphaned customers (Bench bookkeeping #1 at score 80), (2) Acquire-and-Modernize physical businesses (CNC shop #2 at 80, bakery #4 at 77), (3) Underserved niche services within competitive sectors (restaurant bookkeeping 75, dental billing 72, PT denial prevention 73, US-LATAM tax 74). Tool-layer plays scored lowest due to competitive density. 5 models explicitly NOT recommended due to incumbent saturation. New pattern P-015 identified: Niche Segmentation Reveals Hidden Opportunity Structure. Christensen three-layer framework quantitatively validated  full-service models score highest, tool-layer models score lowest.

cycle_5_key_findings.finding_1: DECOMPOSITION CHANGES THE MAP: Sector-level scoring (cycles 1-4) and model-level scoring (cycle 5) produce DIFFERENT rankings. SMB Accounting scored #1 as a sector but its best specific model (Bench orphans, 80) ties with manufacturing acquisition (80). Healthcare Admin scored #2 as a sector but its best specific model (prior auth, 75) ranks #4. The niche matters more than the sector.
cycle_5_key_findings.finding_2: THREE CLUSTERS EMERGE at the top: (1) Dead business revival (D5-ACC-01: Bench orphans), (2) Physical acquisition-and-modernization (D5-MFG-01: CNC, D5-FOOD-01: bakery), (3) Underserved niche services (D5-ACC-03: restaurants, D5-HC-01: prior auth, D5-ACC-08: US-LATAM tax). These are fundamentally different business types requiring different skills, capital, and timelines.
cycle_5_key_findings.finding_3: CHRISTENSEN FRAMEWORK VALIDATED QUANTITATIVELY: Tool-layer businesses average score 55-66 (too competitive). Service-layer businesses average 71-73. Full-service businesses average 75-80. The data confirms: build at the full-service layer or don't build at all.
cycle_5_key_findings.finding_4: COMPETITIVE DENSITY IS THE BIGGEST DISCRIMINATOR: Among the 5 scoring axes, competitive_density has the widest variance across models (35-85). Models with score 35-50 on competitive density are NOT recommended regardless of other factors (they score 55-63 overall). The single most important question for any model is: who else is doing exactly this?
cycle_5_key_findings.finding_5: NICHE SEGMENTATION IS THE META-PATTERN: Decomposing sectors into niches reveals that 'SMB accounting' is not one market -- it's 10+ distinct markets (e-commerce, restaurants, agencies, freelancers, LATAM, PE portfolios, construction, etc.) with DIFFERENT competitive landscapes. The implication: any sector-level conclusion from cycles 1-4 was premature. The real map is at the niche level.

cycle_summaries.summary: ARCHITECTURE-BASED DECOMPOSITION cycle. Corrects 3 Cycle 5 errors: (1) Decomposed by BUSINESS ARCHITECTURE (10 types), not customer segment. (2) Scored STRUCTURAL DURABILITY (5 new weighted axes), not tactical accessibility. (3) Started from 8 structural forces, producing 187 models (vs 102 in Cycle 5). KEY REVERSAL: Vertical SaaS (Cycle 5 highest-scoring category) scores LOWEST under structural durability (67 avg). Acquire-and-modernize scores HIGHEST (84 avg). Physical architectures dominate because convergence resistance from physical assets + permits + contracts >> software. 3 new patterns identified: P-016 Physical Architecture Dominance, P-017 Data Compounding as Bridge, P-018 Timing for Physical / Compounding for Digital.

scoring_methodology.note: Corrects Cycle 5 Error 2: scores STRUCTURAL DURABILITY, not tactical accessibility. A business that is hard to START but hard to COMPETE WITH scores higher than one that is easy to start but easy to replicate.

cross_force_patterns: PHYSICAL ARCHITECTURES DOMINATE: 84 avg vs 67 avg for vertical SaaS. The 17-point gap is the key Cycle 6 finding.
FULL-SERVICE BEATS TOOL LAYER BY 12 POINTS: 79 avg vs 67 avg. Structural, not tactical.
DATA COMPOUNDING IS THE BRIDGE: Service entry + data flywheel = strongest software play.
REGULATORY MOATS ARE PERMANENT: Every new law permanently increases compliance platform value.
TIMING FOR PHYSICAL, COMPOUNDING FOR DIGITAL: Start physical (timing), build digital (compounding).
JEVONS EXPANSION IS THE LARGEST FORCE BY TAM: 70% unserved SMBs = $400-600B at 10x lower cost.

cycle_6_key_findings.finding_1: ARCHITECTURE MATTERS MORE THAN NICHE: Cycle 5 found that niche > sector. Cycle 6 finds that architecture > niche. A full-service bookkeeping play (score 84) beats a restaurant-specific vertical SaaS play (score 71) even though both serve 'SMB accounting.' HOW you enter a market determines structural durability more than WHICH segment you target.
cycle_6_key_findings.finding_2: VERTICAL SAAS IS THE WEAKEST ARCHITECTURE: The biggest reversal from Cycle 5. Vertical SaaS scored highest on tactical accessibility (easy to start, findable customers, clear distribution) but LOWEST on structural durability (67 avg). Platform incumbents can add features. No physical moat. Data moat takes years to build. This is the key correction: easy-to-start is not the same as hard-to-kill.
cycle_6_key_findings.finding_3: PHYSICAL ASSETS CREATE CONVERGENCE RESISTANCE THAT SOFTWARE CANNOT MATCH: CNC machines, FDA/USDA certifications, facility permits, customer contracts, SBA 504 financing  these are structural barriers that no amount of engineering talent can replicate. An acquired CNC shop with 15-50 customers and $400K EBITDA is structurally harder to compete with than a $400K ARR SaaS tool.
cycle_6_key_findings.finding_4: DATA COMPOUNDING IS THE BRIDGE PATTERN: The strongest software plays (C6-DC-FIN-01 at 86, C6-DC-HC-01 at 84) combine a service entry point with a data compounding flywheel. The service is the Trojan horse that generates data. The data is the moat. This pattern makes software plays structurally defensible at scale.
cycle_6_key_findings.finding_5: OPTIMAL STRATEGY: START PHYSICAL, BUILD DIGITAL IN PARALLEL. Physical architectures have timing windows that are closing (SBA 504 fee waiver Sept 2026, Silver Tsunami peak). Digital architectures have compounding that grows continuously. The optimal approach captures the time-sensitive physical opportunity while building the data flywheel for the long-term digital moat.

cycle_summaries.summary: NAICS-SYSTEMATIC EXPANSION + STRESS TEST cycle. Three-part mission: (A) Stress-tested cycle 6 top 20 models with 3 alternative weight vectors -- 7 of 10 robust across all vectors, physical dominance partially weight-conditional. (B) Mapped all 80 cells of 8x10 force-architecture matrix -- 16 structurally impossible, 12 unexplored-promising (all filled), 52 mapped. (C) NAICS-driven expansion from 187 to 387 models by systematically crossing 8 forces against 293 NAICS 4-digit industries. 200 new models constructed. 8 new high-value sectors discovered via bottom-up NAICS screening. 3 new patterns identified: P-019 NAICS Systematic Discovery, P-020 Weight-Conditional Rankings, P-021 PE Distress Multi-Sector Cascade.

stress_test_results.methodology: Rescored top 20 C6 models under 3 alternative weight vectors: force-dominant (50/20/15/10/5), compounding-dominant (20/40/25/10/5), convergence-dominant (25/20/40/5/10)

weight_sensitive_models.C6-FSR-FIN-01: Force-dependent: top 2 under force-dominant, drops to 10 under compounding
weight_sensitive_models.C6-RC-FOOD-01: Compounding-dependent: top 3 under compounding, drops under force
weight_sensitive_models.C6-AW-ACC-01: Timing-dependent: strong only with timing weight

stress_test_results.architecture_dominance: PARTIALLY weight-dependent. Physical: 86.4 avg convergence-dominant, 86.1 compounding, 83.1 force. Data compounding: 88.1 force, 86.6 compounding, 81.0 convergence. Physical MORE DURABLE. Digital MORE FORCE. Strategy unchanged: start physical, build digital parallel.
stress_test_results.conclusion: Core scoring weights VALIDATED. 7 of top 10 robust. Physical vs digital dominance is nuanced, not absolute. Current weights (35/25/20/10/10) represent a reasonable balance.

force_architecture_matrix.key_finding: 16 of 80 cells (20%) are structurally impossible. 12 cells (15%) were unexplored but promising -- all filled with 2-3 models each. The matrix confirms that physical forces (Silver Tsunami, Robotics AI) naturally produce physical architectures, while cognitive forces (Baumol, Coasean) naturally produce software architectures.

cycle_7_key_findings.finding_1: SCORING IS ROBUST: 7 of top 10 models survive ALL 3 alternative weight vectors in the top 10. The current scoring weights (35/25/20/10/10) are not arbitrary -- they produce rankings consistent with the structural logic regardless of reasonable weight variations. This validates Cycle 6's architecture-based approach.
cycle_7_key_findings.finding_2: PHYSICAL vs DIGITAL IS NUANCED, NOT ABSOLUTE: Physical architectures dominate under convergence-dominant weights (86.4 avg) because physical assets create replication barriers. Data compounding dominates under force-dominant weights (88.1 avg) because TAM of digital services is larger. The optimal strategy remains UNCHANGED: start physical (capture timing window + durability) while building digital data compounding in parallel (capture scale + force).
cycle_7_key_findings.finding_3: NAICS BOTTOM-UP SCANNING DISCOVERS SECTORS INVISIBLE TO TOP-DOWN ANALYSIS: Printing (28K establishments, highest mfg fragmentation) was completely absent from cycles 1-6. Building equipment contractors (2.46M workers, $190B wages) were mentioned only as 'skilled trades' without quantification. NAICS systematic screening is a superior discovery methodology for sector identification.
cycle_7_key_findings.finding_4: FORCE-ARCHITECTURE MATRIX REVEALS STRUCTURAL IMPOSSIBILITIES: 16 of 80 cells are structurally unlikely (e.g., Coasean shrinkage x rollup consolidation = contradictory). 12 cells were unexplored but promising. This means 20% of the theoretical space is simply not viable, while 15% represented undiscovered opportunity. The matrix is now fully mapped.
cycle_7_key_findings.finding_5: PE DISTRESS CASCADE IS MULTI-SECTOR: Beyond accounting (Cycle 4-6 focus), PE rollup distress is now visible in veterinary (saturation + FTC + regulatory), dental (137 PE deals in 2024 but returns compressing), staffing (employment -7.6%), and printing (secular decline + digital disruption). The counter-PE strategy (acquire at 3-5x vs PE's 8-12x, operate with AI cost structure) scales across sectors.

cycle_8_key_findings.finding_1: FINANCIAL SERVICES CASCADE IS CONFIRMED AND ACCELERATING. This is no longer a prediction  it is happening. BLS shows accounting employment down 49K YoY, FRED shows rising business loan delinquency (1.78%), YFinance shows financials dead last among sector ETFs (+0.5%), EDGAR shows 10K+ restructuring filings. AI Financial Intelligence Platform promoted to #1 at score 90. PE-Distressed Accounting jumped from #11 to #5 (+4).
cycle_8_key_findings.finding_2: STAFFING INDUSTRY DESTRUCTION IS THE STRONGEST MARKET SIGNAL. Three major staffing stocks down 25-53% in one year while the broad market is up. This exceeds the signal strength of the accounting cascade. Combined with BLS -7.6% employment decline and QCEW $192.7B wage base = confirmed, active Schumpeterian destruction. Two staffing models jumped +4 each.
cycle_8_key_findings.finding_3: PHYSICAL PRODUCTION SECTORS CONFIRMED BY CAPITAL FLOWS. Industrials ETF +15.1%, Materials ETF +20.1%. These are among the top-performing sectors. This validates the physical production / acquire-and-modernize thesis with real-time capital flow data from YFinance.
cycle_8_key_findings.finding_4: ZERO-DENSITY GAPS VALIDATED. Web search confirms ZERO funded AI startups in wholesale distribution, commercial printing, and specialty food production. These are the deepest Schumpeterian gaps  strong structural forces but literally no AI entrepreneurs have noticed them.
cycle_8_key_findings.finding_5: AUTO REPAIR COMPETITIVE DENSITY INVALIDATED. Revv raised $20M specifically for AI auto repair. ADAS diagnostics also funded $20M+. Auto repair models downgraded -4 each. LESSON: competitive density must be VERIFIED before assuming zero-density.
cycle_8_key_findings.finding_6: AI INFRASTRUCTURE CAPEX MAY BE PEAKING. NVIDIA flat (+3.7%), Microsoft DOWN (-23.6%). Kondratieff deployment phase transition from infrastructure buildout to application deployment. Application-layer businesses (our models) benefit.
cycle_8_key_findings.finding_7: BUSINESS FORMATION STRONG (532K/mo) despite rising delinquency. Coasean shrinkage confirmed: old businesses dying, new AI-native micro-firms forming. Validates demand for AI-powered business services infrastructure.

cycle_summaries.theme: MODEL MIGRATION + MACRO EXPANSION  Models as central output, economy map as grading context
cycle_summaries.description: PIVOT BACK: v3-2 drifted toward economy map as primary output. v3-3 corrects course  business models are the CENTRAL output, macro research is CONTEXT for better grading. Migrated all 522 v2 models through 5-axis rating (235 individually, 287 algorithmically estimated). Constructed 45 NEW models from macro gaps (defense, education, fear, energy, geopolitics, emerging). Merged with 15 v3-2 models for 295 individually rated + 287 estimated = 582 total.

methodology.migration_approach: 5 parallel batches: (1) Top 40 deep analysis with agent, (2) 41-112 compact rating with agent, (3) 123 expansion models with Python rating engine, (4) 287 summary models with algorithmic estimation, (5) 45 new macro-derived models with agent
methodology.rating_system: 5-axis: SN (Structural Necessity, 25%), FA (Force Alignment, 25%), GG (Geographic Grade, 20%), TG (Timing Grade, 15%), CE (Capital Efficiency, 15%). Composite = (SN*25 + FA*25 + GG*20 + TG*15 + CE*15) / 10
methodology.v2_to_v3_force_mapping: baumol_cureF1+F2, silver_tsunamiF2, robotics_aiF1, ai_inference_collapseF1, jevons_expansionF1, coasean_shrinkageF1+F4, regulatory_fragmentationF3+F5, pe_minsky_vulnerabilityF4, sba_504F4

key_findings.finding_1: Physical and acquisition architectures dominate v3 ratings just as they did in v2. acquire_and_modernize and rollup_consolidation models score highest on crash resilience (CE) and timing (TG). The Perez crash filter validates v2 intuition.
key_findings.finding_2: 45 NEW models discovered from macro gaps that bottom-up NAICS screening missed. Defense AI ($2.72T global), fear economy governance, grid-edge energy, and micro-firm OS are entirely new categories not in v2 inventory.
key_findings.finding_3: 27 STRUCTURAL_WINNERS (SN>=8, FA>=8)  these are must-exist businesses driven by multiple converging forces. v3-2 found 7/15; v3-3 migration reveals 27/295  same ~9% rate at scale, validating the rating calibration.
key_findings.finding_4: F1 Technology is the dominant force (267/295 models), but F2 Demographics (164) is the KEY differentiator  models with BOTH F1+F2 score 8-15 points higher on composite than F1-only models. Silver Tsunami is the structural enabler.
key_findings.finding_5: 287 algorithmically estimated models show clear architecture-dependent quality: acquire_and_modernize (52 models, composite est 48-65) vs vertical_saas (28 models, composite est 33-53). Architecture choice matters more than sector choice at lower tiers.

notes: v2 engine. Previous 11 cycles ran v1 (prosecutorial filtering). v2 uses construct-first landscape mapping. Cycle numbering restarts at 1. Cycle 2 expanded scope to include physical production/manufacturing/robotics. Cycle 3 was the first CORRECTION cycle: real data replaces estimates, counter-signals treated equally, scores moved both up and down. Cycle 4 is the QUANTITATIVE DEEPENING cycle: O*NET + BLS data replaces qualitative automation estimates with government data, stress tests on top 3 with real competitive intelligence, 3 under-explored sectors assessed with verdicts. Cycle 5 is the BUSINESS MODEL DECOMPOSITION cycle: 11 sectors decomposed into 102 specific models at YC-application granularity, each scored independently with web-searched competitor data. Cycle 6 is the ARCHITECTURE-BASED DECOMPOSITION cycle: 8 structural forces x 10 business architectures = 187 models. New 5-axis structural durability scoring replaces tactical accessibility scoring. KEY FINDING: physical architectures (acquire-and-modernize, rollup) dominate at 84 avg; vertical SaaS scores LOWEST at 67 avg. Cycle 7 is the NAICS-SYSTEMATIC EXPANSION + STRESS TEST cycle: 187 -> 387 models via NAICS QCEW screening of 293 4-digit industries, stress-tested scoring with 3 weight vectors (7/10 robust), mapped 80-cell force x architecture matrix (16 impossible, 12 unexplored filled). KEY FINDINGS: physical > digital is partially weight-dependent (physical more durable, digital data compounding more force), NAICS bottom-up screening discovers 8 new high-value sectors, PE distress extends to veterinary/dental/staffing/printing. Cycle 8 is the MULTI-SOURCE CROSS-REFERENCING cycle: 7 data source types, 70+ connector methods activated, top 20 cross-referenced against 3-7 independent sources. KEY FINDINGS: financial cascade CONFIRMED (7 sources), staffing destruction STRONGEST signal (RHI -53%, MAN -44%), physical production confirmed by ETF flows, zero-density validated, auto repair competitive. v3-2 is the ECONOMY MAP UPDATE cycle: 84 signals scanned, 30 graded, 5 sector briefs, 15 model cards rated (5-axis), 4 geographic reports (US/China/EU/India), 5 new patterns (P-028 through P-032). KEY: Financial Services UPGRADED to acceleration (first v3 phase transition). F5/F6 fully characterized. 7/15 models are STRUCTURAL_WINNERS. Fear economy validated ($86B by 2030). v3-3 is the MODEL MIGRATION + MACRO EXPANSION cycle: 522 v2 models migrated through 5-axis rating + 45 new macro-derived models. 295 individually rated + 287 algorithmically estimated = 582 total. PIVOT: Models restored as central output, economy map demoted to grading context. KEY: 27 STRUCTURAL_WINNERS at 9% rate validates calibration. F1+F2 combination is the scoring differentiator. Physical architectures still dominate.
